label: ENTERPRISE & SECURITY
title: Single-Tenant SaaS (STS) Launch
description: I led the 0→1 launch of a new single-tenant SaaS deployment model designed for enterprise and regulated customers who needed stronger isolation without losing SaaS velocity. I owned discovery, requirements, pricing inputs, and GTM enablement, turning a trust-and-compliance gap into a scalable product line that drove meaningful revenue impact.

meta.proudOf: Turning enterprise security needs into a repeatable product + sales motion that scaled rapidly
meta.learned: Narrative clarity and early cross-functional alignment matter as much as technical correctness in executive-visible launches

sections.label: STS
sections.heading: Context
sections.content:
DataRobot served two ends of the deployment spectrum:

- **Multi-tenant SaaS:** Fast feature delivery, but some customers needed stronger isolation guarantees.
- **On-prem:** Strong isolation, but slow upgrades and heavy operational burden (Kubernetes, infra complexity, long deployment timelines).

A growing segment of enterprise and regulated customers wanted **SaaS velocity with single-tenant security posture**. Without it, we were losing or stalling deals that required clearer guarantees around isolation, governance, and compliance.

sections.label: STS
sections.heading: Goals and Success Criteria
sections.content:
I aligned leadership, Engineering, Security, and Sales on measurable success criteria:

- **Unlock new enterprise and regulated revenue** we couldn’t win with existing deployment options
- **Reduce deployment and upgrade friction** relative to on-prem
- **Preserve SaaS velocity** (customers should get new features quickly)
- **Improve sales confidence** with clear positioning, pricing, and enablement

We treated STS as a *first-class product line*, not a one-off deployment exception.

sections.label: STS
sections.heading: Key Product Decisions
sections.content:
**1) STS as a first-class SKU**
- Defined STS as a distinct offering with its own scope, roadmap, and requirements.
- Avoided a support-heavy “special case” that would degrade over time.

**2) Security-first positioning**
- Led with isolation guarantees and a clear threat model.
- Created a narrative that Sales could repeat consistently.

**3) “Your Own Castle” analogy**
- I developed a simple metaphor to make the architecture intuitive:
  - Multi-tenant = shared fortress.
  - STS = **your own castle with your own guards**.
- This materially improved sales conversations by making security posture legible to non-technical stakeholders.

**4) Pricing for value (not just cost)**
- Partnered with Engineering to understand cost drivers.
- Worked with Pricing and Sales to validate willingness-to-pay.
- Landed pricing that reflected the *security + operational value* while preserving margins and scaling with customer size.

sections.label: STS
sections.heading: Execution
sections.content:
I drove delivery end-to-end across product, engineering, security, pricing, and GTM.

**Discovery & Requirements**
- Conducted discovery with customers, prospects, and internal Success/Sales teams.
- Authored the core PRD and requirements, translating ambiguous compliance needs into concrete capabilities.

**Cross-functional delivery**
- Coordinated engineering work across multiple teams.
- Built decision docs to align on security model and operational responsibilities.

**GTM enablement**
- Created enablement materials (positioning docs, FAQs, sales narratives).
- Joined customer calls to explain architecture and security posture directly.
- Supported active deal cycles, helping close and accelerate multiple six-figure contracts.

**Validation before full automation**
- Before investing heavily in automation, we proved demand by supporting early deals manually.
- This de-risked the architecture and pricing while we iterated on the sales motion.

sections.label: STS
sections.heading: Impact
sections.content:
STS became a meaningful part of the business quickly:

- **40+ customers adopted STS**.
- **10%+ of ARR** attributable to the product line at the time I departed.
- **Multiple large enterprise deals** were directly influenced or closed through STS.

Beyond the headline numbers, STS changed how the company sold trust:
- We turned security/compliance requirements into a repeatable product narrative.
- Sales teams gained confidence in positioning because the offering was clearly defined (not “custom”).

sections.label: STS
sections.heading: What Worked, What I’d Improve
sections.content:
**What worked**
- Treating STS as a true product line created clarity, ownership, and scalability.
- Security-first narrative made value obvious and differentiated us from “SaaS-only” competitors.
- Early alignment with Sales, Pricing, and Security reduced late-stage deal friction.

**What I’d do differently**
- Invest earlier in self-service deployment tooling to reduce operational load.
- Tighten post-launch feedback loops to identify expansion and retention opportunities sooner.
- Formalize upgrade paths from multi-tenant → STS so customers could grow into the model.

**What I’d do next**
- Expand into additional regulated verticals with tighter compliance packaging.
- Bundle STS with premium security features for clearer upsell ladders.
- Build a guided “migration” experience to reduce switching friction.

**Growth PM takeaway**
- Enterprise growth often hinges on *trust* as much as features.
- The win wasn’t just shipping architecture — it was building a repeatable story + SKU + GTM motion that turned compliance needs into revenue.
